items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: High river levels are expected to cause flooding on 5th February 2026. Further rainfall is forecast today and tomorrow, and river levels will remain high. During periods of high tide, the River Nene will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding of the North Bank Road, between Peterborough and Rings End. Whilst this Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes have been put in place and further updates will be available through local media. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Refer to Local Authority website for road closures. This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 6th February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message: High river levels today, 05 February 2026 may lead to flooding. This information is correct as of 3:30pm on Thursday 05 February 2026. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 18cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 7cm of water on the road. There are currently no issues on Earith causeway. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close the road. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. We are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourse. This message will be updated by 8:00am on Friday 06 February 2026 or as the situation changes

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message: The River Yeo level remains high at 8.23m and the drain level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 8.48m and stable. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. Flooding will affect the Langport to Muchelney road if this drain level exceeds 7.30m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Draycott road above 8.80m. Pumping will start at Huish Episcopi and Westover stations once river levels allow. We will operate the River Sowy (Parrett Relief Channel) as conditions allow. Bands of rain, heavy at times, are forecast for today, Thursday 5th February, and during Friday. Catchments are saturated and rivers are expected to be very responsive to the forecast rainfall. We continue to monitor the situation closely. Staff are checking the condition of flood banks and spillways. Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on 6 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

The high tide at Falmouth on Thursday is 19:55 and Friday morning is at 08:09, times of high water will vary along the coast. Forecast total high tide level is 2.53m & 2.74mAOD respectively. Expect tide levels along the coast to be between 0.5 and 0.7 metres above tide table level. Force 4 south easterly winds tonight moving to force 4 South Westerly winds on Friday and offshore wave heights of over 2m are forecast.

The River Tone level at Currymoor Pumping Station is 7.61m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45m. The Drain level at Currymoor Pumping Station is currently 7.61m. Cutts Road and New Road are both closed. Water is flowing out of Currymoor over Athelney Spillway and the A361 is also closed. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor, and additional pumps are operational at Northmoor. Bands of rain, heavy at times, are forecast for today, Thursday 5th February, and into tomorrow. Catchments are saturated and rivers are expected to be very responsive to the forecast rainfall. We continue to monitor the situation closely and staff are checking flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on 6th February 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels today may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on 06/02/2026 because of the combination of river flows and high tides. The next high tide is forecast 01:30 and 03:45 on Friday morning (06/02/2026). The water level is expected to be 5.04 metres Chart Datum (2.30 mAOD). Flooding will affect the access road and car parking areas near the White Swan Pub and car garage at Mansbridge. Water may be forced up through the floor of the Pub. Riverside Park will also be flooded. Levels may also be very high around Gaters Mill. Friday's tide at 13:45 on 06/02/2026 is forecast to be 5cm lower. Flooding impacts will be similar. Rain is expected to continue until Friday evening (06/02/2026) so river flows will remain high. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are liaising with Southampton City Council on operation of Woodmill. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have. Including defences around the White Swan pub. This message will be updated by 06/02/2026 19:00.

High tides on Friday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible for 1 hour either side of Friday's early morning tide at 02:03 on 06/02/2026. 
The weather increases tide table values by 0.5 m. The total forecast tide is 5.16 metres Chart Datum (2.43 mAOD) at Portsmouth. Light South Easterly Force 4 wind. Impacts will be relatively minor and confined to the immediate sea front. Water will be high at South Street and Queen Street, Emsworth. The Ship Inn car park, Langstone will flood. Water will flow into the road at Langstone High Street, but flood depths will be relatively shallow. Friday's tide at 14:06 06/02/2026 is forecast to be 12 cm lower (2.31 mAOD). 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . Particularly if directly on the harbour front. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 06 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message: High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible from 2nd February 2026 onwards. Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We are closely monitoring the situation . Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . This message will be updated by 1:00PM on 9 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Thursday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 05 February 2026 as further rain (25mm) is forecast throughout today. 
If as much rain falls as forecast, flooding could affect the recreation ground at Fleming Park, and the river will be very high at Kingfisher Road. Surface water flooding could affect roads in Chandlers Ford, and at Stoneham Way from Chestnut Way to the M27. A similar event to Tuesday (03/02/2026). More rain is forecast on Friday (06/02/2026) and Saturday (07/02/2026). This will potentially increase flood risk further. River levels might not fall until Sunday (08/02/2026). 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. 
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions . Report blockages to our hotline 0800 80 70 60. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 06 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages.

Consider activating any flood protection products you may have. Avoid driving through watersplash areas in Brockenhurst.

items.description: Middle Hampshire Avon from Salisbury to Ringwood
items.message: This is a Flood Warning Update. River levels remain high due to prolonged rainfall and high groundwater levels. Flooding is still possible. Areas most at risk include areas in Britford, Charlton All Saints, Downton and Fordingbridge in close proximity to the River Avon. Further rain is expected over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. Never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. Check local authority websites for road closures. This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 6 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor Pumping Station is 7.61m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45m. The Drain level at Currymoor Pumping Station is currently 7.61m. Cutts Road and New Road remain closed. Water is flowing out of Currymoor over Athelney Spillway and the A361 remains closed. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if the Drain level reaches 8.30m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. Bands of rain, heavy at times, are forecast for today, Thursday 5th February, and into tomorrow. Catchments are saturated and rivers are expected to be very responsive to the forecast rainfall.  We are monitoring the situation closely and checking flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please avoid driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1PM on 06/02/2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Friday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 06 February 2026 Another 10-20mm of rain is forecast Thursday pm to Friday pm 
From 22:00 05/02/2026, minor flood impacts could affect Barnham Road and Lake Lane. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, land at Riverside Caravan Centre, and could affect the car park at Tescos on Shripney Road. The Aldingbourne Rife will rise between Thursday evening and Friday evening. Rising roughly 20cm, before falling slightly Saturday. More rain is forecast Saturday evening. It could be possible for water to be close to Durban Road on Sunday. Flood risk will continue to at least Monday. River levels in Bersted will remain higher than normal for a fortnight. 
We are closely monitoring the situation clearing debris screens through Barnham. Our pumps at Felpham are running. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have Including in Barnham. Avoid roads that flood (Barnham Rd and Lake Lane). 
This message will be updated by 8:00PM on 06 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Friday may lead to flooding.

If as much rain falls as predicted Thursday and Friday, from 07:00 06/02/2026 flooding could affect fields, roads, and gardens of isolated riverside properties at Loxley Bridge on Wrotham Hill, Dunsfold and Petworth Road, Chiddingfold. Also gardens near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and the Onslow Arms, Loxwood. River levels and flood risk should initially begin to fall late Friday night, but more rain is forecast Saturday evening. More flood impacts could be possible this weekend. 
We are closely monitoring the situation

This message will be updated by 8:00PM on 06 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Plymouth Sound, Wembury Bay and tidal estuaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.  
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.    
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.    
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: South Hayling and South Eastoke seafront
items.message:
High tides are expected to cause flooding on Friday. 
Flooding is expected for 2 hours either side of Friday's early morning tide and early afternoon tide on 06/02/2026   
For the tide at 02:03, the weather increases tide table values by 0.5 m. The total forecast tide is 5.16 metres Chart Datum (2.43 mAOD) at Portsmouth. Light South Easterly Force 4 wind. The tide at 14:06, is forecast to be 12cm lower (2.31 mAOD). The shingle beach at Eastoke Corner has been impacted by high energy waves. Water could push further up the beach than normal. Property at Eastoke corner, near the nature reserve, and Southwood Road may flood. Overtopping of splash walls along the beach front may flood gardens. Beach huts at West Beach, near the Inn on the beach may be affected. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Activate any flood protection products you may have . Avoid South Hayling seafront. Shingle can be thrown by wind and waves. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 06 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and Parrett, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Parrett, River Cary

items.message: Considerable floodwater remains on the Somerset Levels and Moors and upstream river levels remain high. Areas most at risk include locations near the River Yeo, River Parrett and River Cary, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around the Ilchester to Yeovilton road at the end of runway.  Bands of rain, heavy at times, are forecast for today, Thursday 5th February, and during Friday. Catchments are saturated and rivers are expected to be very responsive to the forecast rainfall. We continue to monitor the situation and Field Teams are out clearing debris screens and checking rivers for blockages. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions and don’t put yourself or others at risk. This message will be updated by 1pm on 6 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Thursday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 05 February 2026 , as a lot of rain (25mm) is forecast. 
If as much rain falls as is forecast, flooding could affect roads through East Meon, West Meon, including Lynch Lane, Shoe Lane and Church Lane, Exton and Bucks Head Hill at Meonstoke. The river may flood gardens and the Millennium Water Meadows at Wickham. With further rain forecast Friday (06/02/2026) and Saturday (07/02/2026) river levels and flood risk are likely to remain high until Sunday (08/02/2026). 
We are closely monitoring the situation and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . Particularly properties close to the river, or with pumps for groundwater 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 06 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cerne Valley
items.message:
High groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding. Flooding is expected from 03 February 2026. Groundwater levels in West Dorset are beginning to fall but remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Charminster and nearby areas. The groundwater level at the Dickley Down borehole has risen to 166.70m. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. We are closely monitoring the situation. If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts.
 
This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 10 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

Groundwater levels in West Dorset remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Hooke, Toller Whelme and Toller Porcorum. The groundwater level at the Dickley Down borehole is 165.97m, and is expected to remain high. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. Roads may have become damaged by floodwater. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. This message will be updated by 11:00 on 11 February 2026.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Pimperne Brook
items.message: This is a Groundwater Flood Warning Update. Groundwater levels in Cranborne Chase remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Pimperne Brook at Pimperne. The groundwater level at Iwerne Hill Farm borehole is 115.23m, and is expected to remain high over the next few days. Flooding of roads and some properties, especially basements is expected. Residents should continue to keep any property resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers deployed. Further rainfall is forecast throughout the week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Keep up to date with groundwater levels on the 'Check for Flooding' site on gov.uk. Please take care and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. Never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 11 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is currently 7.61m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.61m. Cutts Road and New Road remain closed. Athelney spillway is running and the A361 remains closed. For road closure information please see www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. The River Tone level is still too high to pump at Currymoor. We will commence pumping here once river levels allow. We operate the River Sowy relief channel as conditions allow. Bands of rain, heavy at times, are forecast for today, Thursday 5th February, and into tomorrow. Catchments are saturated and rivers are expected to be very responsive to the forecast rainfall. We are monitoring the situation closely and checking floodbanks and spillways. Please do not walk, cycle or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on 06/02/2026, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Meon Valley from East Meon to Soberton
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible , as a lot of rain (56mm) fell in the last week. 
Flooding is affecting the electricity sub station in Rectory Lane, Meonstoke. The Winterbourne will be flowing across Rectory Lane, Meonstoke and behind the Buck's Head Pub. From Thursday (05/02/2026), flooding will effect the Bucks Head pub. Further rain (up to 20mm) is forecast to affect Hampshire on each of Thursday (05/02/2026) and Friday (06/02/2026).  If heavy rain continues into next week, then it is possible that more extensive flooding affecting cellars in Exton, as well as a number of properties in Corhampton and Meonstoke could occur in the next 2 weeks. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 10 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible , as over a month's rain (71mm) has fallen in the last week. 
Flooding is affecting cellars of properties in West Street. From today (04/02/2026), cellar flooding will begin to affect properties on East Street. It is possible that cellar flooding will become widespread in Hambledon by this weekend. Further rain (up to 20mm) is forecast on Thursday (05/02/2026). From Friday (06/02/2026) to Sunday (08/02/2026), lighter rain is forecast. Groundwater levels in Hambledon are expected to continue rising into next week. Flooding impacts will increase during this time. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with Hambledon Flood Action Group. 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 11 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Thursday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 05 February 2026 Another 10-20mm of rain is forecast Thursday pm to Friday pm 
The River Ems is expected to rise on Thursday evening and Friday morning, possibly a little higher than in recent days. From 21:00 05/02/2026 minor flooding could affect fields, Brook Meadows, rural roads, and gardens of properties on North Street, River Street and at the Wren Centre, Westbourne. Also near Lumley Mill and Victoria Terrace, Emsworth. River levels should recover slightly Friday afternoon before more rain and flood risk is forecast Saturday evening. It could be possible for water to be close to properties Saturday evening. River levels will remain high through February. 
We are closely monitoring the situation operating our structure at Constant Springs, and clearing debris screens. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have Including in Westbourne and Emsworth, flooding may occur quickly. 
This message will be updated by 8:00PM on 06 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high, and flooding of gardens and the Millennium Water Meadows at Wickham, is expected to continue. Today 15mm of rainfall has fallen, and rainfall is forecast to continue for the remainder of the day. Further rain is forecast tomorrow Friday (06/02/2026) and Saturday (07/02/2026). River levels are rising, and flooding could further affect the Millennium Meadows, and commercial and industrial property downstream of the main A334 Fareham Road could flood. Access to property in Bridge Street could be affected. River levels will remain higher than normal, and flood risk will continue into the weekend. Ensure any flood protection products you have are activated. This message will be updated by 18:00 Friday 06/02/2026.

items.description: Salt Moor and North Moor including Moorland
items.message: Water levels in Saltmoor and Northmoor remain high today, Thursday 5th February. The drain level at Northmoor pumping station is 3.72 m and at North Moor Main Drain Remote is 4.48 m.  The level in Currymoor is stable, though still very high. Athelney spillway is still running into Saltmoor and Northmoor. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. We are undertaking works to improve the flow along Northmoor Main Drain to maximise pumping into the Parrett. The River Tone level is still too high to pump at Currymoor. We will start pumping here once river levels allow. We operate the River Sowy (Parrett Relief Channel) as conditions allow. Bands of rain, heavy at times, are forecast for today, Thursday 5th February, and into tomorrow. Catchments are saturated and rivers are expected to be very responsive to the rainfall. We are monitoring the situation closely and checking floodbanks and spillways. Remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 1PM on 06 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

Groundwater is high, but currently falling at the Houndean Bottom borehole. Light rain is forecast for much of Sunday. Even at such short lead times there is uncertainty in amounts. 20mm of rain could be recorded Sunday. Another 10-15mm of rain is forecast for Tuesday. Groundwater is expected to remain high. Springs will appear, water will affect fields, the recreation ground, and a small number of cellars in Denton. If we get the maximum rain Sunday and Tuesday, then groundwater could rise again, and a small amount of water may appear on Denton Road. Very little rain is forecast mid week. Groundwater rise at Houndean Bottom borehole should pause around 06/02/2026. However, with the weather outlook remaining unsettled, and more rain predicted on Friday, further groundwater rise is possible next weekend. Which may cause water to flow towards Vicarage Close and affect areas near the three ponds in South Heighton. Flood impacts may remain until mid February. Take care on roads that flood (Denton Road). Ensure pumps work. We will monitor, and update this message by 18:00 06/02/2026.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley
items.message: Groundwater is high and slowly rising. Light rain is forecast for much of Sunday. Even at such short lead times there is uncertainty in amounts. 20mm of rain could be recorded Sunday. Another 10-15mm of rain is forecast for Tuesday. Groundwater is expected to continue rising. Springs will appear, water will be in fields, and small amounts of water could flow down roads. If we get the maximum rain Sunday and Tuesday, then groundwater could rise higher and faster. Potentially affecting a small number of cellars in Stoughton and Walderton from 04/02/2026. With more water flowing along Stoughton main road, the road from East Marden, between Cooks Lane and Barley Mow in Walderton, the B2146 near Woodlands Lane. Very little rain is forecast mid week. Groundwater rise at Compton borehole should pause around 07/02/2026. However, with the weather outlook remaining unsettled, and more rain predicted on Friday, further groundwater rise is possible next weekend. Take care on roads that flood (Stoughton, Walderton). Ensure pumps work. We will monitor, and update this message by 18:00 06/02/2026.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Dean, Singleton, Charlton, East Dean and Chilgrove
items.message: Groundwater is high and slowly rising. Light rain is forecast for much of Sunday. Even at such short lead times there is uncertainty in amounts. 20mm of rain could be recorded Sunday. Another 10-15mm of rain is forecast for Tuesday. Groundwater is expected to continue rising. Springs will appear, water will be in fields, small amounts of water will flow down roads, groundwater will affect the ability of the sewage network to operate in East Dean, Charlton, Singleton and West Dean, and may start to appear in a small number of basements. If we get the maximum rain Sunday and Tuesday, then groundwater could rise higher and faster, causing more water to flow on roads. Groundwater rise at Chilgrove borehole should pause around 07/02/2026, but will continue at East Dean borehole until at least the middle of February. With the weather outlook remaining unsettled, and more rain predicted on Friday, further groundwater rise is possible next weekend. Take care on roads that flood (Chilgrove, West Dean, Singleton, East Dean). Ensure pumps work. We will update this message by 18:00 06/02/2026.

This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 06 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Thursday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 05 February 2026 as a lot of rain is forecast (25mm). 
Flooding may affect low lying land and Horsebridge Road, Broughton, and will be close to property at Duck’s Lane, Church Street and The Square at Nether Wallop, where it may flood gardens. Lighter rain (up to 10mm) is forecast on Friday (06/02/2026). River levels will remain higher than normal, and flood risk will continue into the weekend. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 06 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible . Over a month's rain (69mm) has fallen in the last week. 
We expect the Idsworth Lavant to be flowing. Pumps which may prevent water from entering property may be required. Surface water may flood property during heavier rain events. Further rain (up to 20mm) is forecast on Thursday (05/02/2026). Lighter rain is forecast from Friday (06/02/2026) to Sunday (08/02/2026). If heavy rain affects the area, then groundwater levels will rise into next week. From this weekend, road flooding, including Chalton Road in Finchdean, could become deep in all villages. Cellar flooding could occur in Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 11 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kings Somborne and Little Somborne
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible as a lot of rain (45mm) has fallen in the last week. 
Currently, groundwater levels in Kings Somborne are stable around 10cm below where we would expect flooding to begin affecting cellars in a small number of properties along Winchester Road, central King's Somborne and in Little Somborne. Today (05/02/2026), up to 30mm of rain is forecast to affect Hampshire. From Friday (06/02/2026) to Monday (09/02/2026), lighter rain is forecast with another 30mm possible across these 4 days. If heavy rain affects Kings Somborne and Little Somborne, the level will begin rising again and flooding impacts could begin within the next week. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 12 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high, and flooding is continuing to affect Titchfield Hill with very high water levels at Titchfield Mill, Bridge Cottage and at the Tanneries Industrial Estate. Today 10mm of rainfall has fallen, and rainfall is forecast to continue for the remainder of the day. Further rain is forecast tomorrow Friday (06/02/2026) and Saturday (07/02/2026). River levels will rise, and there could be further flooding. While groundwater and river levels are currently so high, any intense rainfall events are now likely to cause surface water flooding in Titchfield High Street. Ensure any flood protection products you have are activated. River levels will remain higher than normal, and flood risk will continue into the weekend. This message will be updated by 16:00 on Friday 06/02/2026.

items.description: Sandown, Brading and Bembridge on the Eastern Yar
items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding on Thursday. 
Flooding is expected on 05 February 2026 , further rain (9mm) has fallen today.   
River levels are high. Flooding is continuing to affect Moreton Common and Golf Links roads. Fort Holiday Park and Sandown Sewage works are continuing to flood as ditches struggle to drain to the main river. Impacts may be continuing at Nicholas Close, Brading. Rain is to continue for the remainder of the day. Further rain is forecast Friday (06/02/2026) and Saturday (07/02/2026). River levels will remain high for the next few days. 
We are checking rivers for blockages and operating Bembridge sluices 
Activate any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 06 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Friday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 06 February 2026 Another 10-20mm of rain is forecast Thursday pm to Friday pm 
The River Lavant will rise on Thursday evening and Friday morning. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, roads and gardens. In East Lavant water may affect Sheepwash Lane, Pook Lane, the Green, and bridges across the river. Water could also approach gardens of properties at The Sadlers in Westhampnett. River levels could be 20cm higher Friday morning than they are Thursday, before falling a little Friday afternoon. More rain is forecast Saturday evening, river levels will rise higher still. Flood risk will continue for at least a week. River levels will remain high most of February. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and operating structures in Westhampnett for the Flood Alleviation Scheme. 
Don't put yourself or others at risk Avoid roads that flood (Sheepwash Lane). Report blockages to 0800 80 70 60. 
This message will be updated by 8:00PM on 06 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tyne estuary at North Shields, South Shields and Howdon Pans
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  
Tidal conditions are expected to improve and no flooding is expected.    
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.    
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

floodArea.county: Hartlepool, North Yorkshire, Redcar and Cleveland

items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 4:00PM to 7:00PM on 05/02/2026. 
Locations most affected will be coastal roads and footpaths, particularly from Hartlepool Headland North to Breakwater. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid beaches and coastal promenades, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 9:00AM on 06 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Littleton, Headbourne, Kings and Martyr Worthy, Easton and Chilland
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 07/02/2026 because of a wet winter season. 
Flooding could affect Springvale Road in Kings Worthy. In the next 3 days, in Martyr Worthy, Chilland and Easton drainage ditches and culverts will become full and less effective as natural flow paths are restricted. Some properties may be affected as water seeps up through floors. Footpaths near the river will also become inaccessible. At Littleton, cellar flooding is unlikely to commence for around 2 weeks. Today (05/02/2026), up to 30mm of rain is forecast. From Friday (06/02/2026) to Monday (09/02/2026), lighter rain is forecast. Groundwater levels will likely to rise into next week. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 12 February 2026 or as the situation changes.
